utterances: But in this case, the degree to which the government has paid for the vaccine research and development is a little bit more than usual when the government contracts and gives its intellectual property to private companies.
Is there something really widely symbolic here that's really representative of the drug industry in that it's taxpayer-funded?
This isn't really the free market, but in the end, a company gets a product and they can say, well, it's the free market.
We can charge 20 times what you think we should charge if there's an emergency and we want to make some money.
Yeah, and that's what people like Dr. Gee in Louisiana say.
They're worried that the taxpayers have paid for this and they will pay again when Medicaid and public health departments have to buy the vaccine.
Yet, the government is not getting any assurance that Sanofi will charge consumers in the U.S.
a fair price or anything similar to what they pay in other countries.
The U.S.
pays more for drugs than any other country in the world.
And is there any reason to suspect this particular company of price gouging?
Let's remember, they haven't actually sold the thing yet.
Well, they aren't any different than other drug companies, but they do charge more in the U.S.
for other drugs than they charge in other countries.
So it's a pattern, and there's no reason to think that they'll do any different here.
OK.
Alison, thanks as always.
Thank you, Steve.
That's NPR's Alison Kodjak this morning.
And one final note as we get your guide to the news today.
Manuel Noriega, the former leader of Panama, has died.
Isn't that a name that's just remained on our consciousness for so many years?
Yeah.
He was a strong man in the 1980s, first an ally of the United States but then really an obstacle.
He was accused of interfering with an election that didn't go his way.
And the United States military under President George H.W.
Bush removed him from power in 1989, blasting rock music at an annoying volume at the building where Manuel Noriega took shelter.
He spent years afterward in and out of prison.
This next story is a story of retaliation.
The U.S.
Senate approved a package of tough financial sanctions against North Korea, Iran and Russia.
This was one way for Congress to punish Moscow for meddling in the 2016 election.
And now Russia has responded.
It says it will shut down a U.S.
embassy retreat outside Moscow and seize warehouse facilities in the area that are used by the U.S.
The Russian government is also ordering the U.S.
to reduce the number of people who work in the U.S.
Embassy and in U.S.
consulates.
To talk about this, we have reached The Wall Street Journal's Tom Grove in Moscow.
Hello there.
Hi.
So what else are you learning about this response by Russia to these U.S.
sanctions?
Are the property seizures a big deal?
I'd say it's more symbolic, whereas, you know, slimming down the diplomatic mission to such a small number obviously will degrade those diplomats' abilities to work in Russia.
The kind of the diplomatic retreat that's being shuttered - it's much more symbolic.
It goes back to diplomatic facilities in the United States that were shuttered by Obama at the end of December last year.
So what kind of reduction in staff at the U.S.
Embassy and consulates does Russia want?
The Russia foreign ministry has made it clear that it wants the U.S.
diplomatic mission to reduce its staff to 455 people.
And who that exactly means is still unclear.
That could be anybody from the cleaning lady to the Russians who work there to the diplomats and the ambassador himself.
So it's - there's a number of levels within the embassy and the consulates.
And it's just not clear right now who they mean.
Right.
And we don't know exactly what the total number of people employed at these places is.
But it's safe to say that that reduction could be hundreds of people.
Is that right?
Absolutely.
We could be talking from anywhere in the low hundreds in some conservative estimates.
I think more people right now are looking at a higher number.
And so what does this response mean about the relationship between the U.S.
and Russia, which was already not very good?
Yeah.
I mean, everybody knew that relations between Russia and the United States were not great.
They were pretty bad.
And they had been that way kind of since 2014.
When Russia annexed Crimea.
Correct.
And obviously, tensions grew even more after the 2016 election.
But there was a window of opportunity in which they could have gotten better - at least that was Moscow's hope.
But with that hope gone in Moscow, you're basically going to see an acceleration of this downward trajectory.
And I mean, you talked about how the news of the sanctions is being received in Moscow.
What else are you hearing there?
What else are people's reactions not just to the sanctions, but to Russia's response?
If you speak to the Russian officials, they say these measures have been a long time coming.
You know, Russia was sanctioned at the end of 2016.
If you remember, there was 35 diplomats that were thrown out of the United States.
They had a diplomatic retreat that was shuttered to them.
And they played this in a very conciliatory manner for a very long time.
And I think it just - it got to the point where Putin realized he would have been losing face if he wouldn't have acted and acted toughly.
Tom Grove of The Wall Street Journal.
We reached him at the Journal's bureau in Moscow.
Thank you so much.
Thank you.
(SOUNDBITE OF MAJOR LAZER SONG, ""KNOW NO BETTER"")
President Trump announced new restrictions on U.S.
travel to Cuba last month, but cruises were allowed to continue.
The cruise industry saw a big opportunity after the Obama administration began allowing Americans to visit Cuba, and the business is growing.
NPR's Greg Allen sent this report from Miami.
(SOUNDBITE OF BOAT HORN)
Nearly every day at the Port of Miami, cruise ships pull away from the docks, headed to Caribbean destinations, places like the Bahamas, Turks and Caicos and increasingly Cuba.
Kim Bird of Dallas was one of those waiting to board a liner to Havana.
Cruised many times.
Cuba's a place I've always wanted to just see.
Bird was with her friend Alyssa Bain, a travel agent from Miami.
Bain is booking a lot of trips to Cuba for clients, and she wanted to check it out for herself.
When she heard last month President Trump was getting ready to announce a new Cuba policy, she was concerned.
At first but now no - as far as travel goes, cruises - definitely no change at all.
What will change is that it largely ends individual travel.
Everyone except Cuban-Americans visiting family now can only go with groups on humanitarian, cultural or educational trips.
That's a policy that leaves cruise ships in the clear.
Cruisers are advised they need to fill out an affidavit and take part in an educational or cultural excursion.
Many of those now going to Cuba are experienced travelers who're looking for a new destination in the Caribbean but want the amenities of a cruise ship.
That's one reason Bain says she didn't consider flying to Cuba.
Well, Jackson Diehl, thanks a lot for talking with us.

But that right to face your accuser guaranteed in the Sixth Amendment to the Constitution wasn't written to apply to impeachment, says David Dorsen, a former assistant chief counsel on the Senate Watergate Committee.
This is not a criminal proceeding.
It's a impeachment proceeding, and the rules of evidence don't apply.
Dorsen says this impeachment inquiry, announced by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, is still in the early stages.
Documents can be introduced, and otherwise, matters can be presented that do not strictly conform to the rules of evidence.
Yale Law professor and former Obama administration lawyer Harold Koh says the purpose of the Sixth Amendment is pretty straightforward.
It's designed to make sure that before someone goes to prison, that they get a chance to confront the person who has charged them with the crime.
And Koh says this ultimately isn't about the whistleblower, whoever they may be.
It's about the documents and potential wrongdoing by the president.
This is a complete canard.
The whole point of having whistleblower complaints is that whistleblowers point to problems, and the problems can then be revealed by documents.
And then the person who is being charged has to demonstrate that the whistleblower is telling falsehoods through the documents.
For now, Trump should worry less about the whistleblower and more about the statements coming from his own legal team, says Larry Gibson, a law professor at the University of Maryland.
Well, you don't often have the person accused producing the smoking gun.
Gibson is referring in part to statements by Rudy Giuliani, the president's lawyer.
Giuliani told Fox News that he was asked by the administration to speak to Ukrainian leaders about investigating the son of Trump's political rival, former Vice President Joe Biden.
